replies.text: My main account is with Schwab but I opened a HSA with fidelity. The fact that fidelity sweeps your cash balance into a money market is reason enough to pick fidelity. I havent switched because of the headache and I just actively manage my cash in a money market act with Schwab but if I was starting from scratch Id pick fidelity.

Fidelity allows for partial shares of ETFs and Stocks. Schwab only allows partial of some stocks on the SP. The source of the funds can come from your brokerage or directly from your bank account. Fidelity allows automatic investing of any stockETF. Schwab only has it for mutual funds. Edit I switched all but my individual stocks from Schwab to Fidelity for the above reasons.
I am with Schwab after being ripped off by Ameriprise and Facet. Have had no issues with Schwab. Good customer service and easy to use for my needs. Cant complain

Coming from TD Ameritrade I am still disappointed with Schwab. Compared to their pc app Schwab is not nearly as easy to use but it does provide the info if you have time to drill and search. I use both TOS for trading and pc app for account and portfolio management. I am planning on moving my managed accounts out of Schwab since they like to use their ETFs over better performing Vangard, etc. I will leave my trading accounts with Schwab just because of TOS.
Schwab for me simple af and I love that. The dark mode is the best. Easy on the eye
Fidelity has 0 fee funds

I have both. Its no big deal wit move stuff to sgov or usfr with free trades. I prefer tos. But I dont trade much anymore. Fidelity does dumb crap where you need like 1 million to trade zero day options. Tda basically banned trading on options of gme and AMC. You couldnt sell covered calls or cash backed puts with the ap. You had to call in and phone trade. Fidelity and Vanguard I think are the only 2 that didnt cut off options trading. Vanguard is no leveraged or crypto. Fidelity also no futures. I keep a couple of accounts due to potential fraud or and or systems crashing. Once I retire I dont want to risk having one get cut off for whatever reason. Its a minor inconvenience with taxed as its another form but I just report totals and upload the document.

Im with fidelity and have never used Schwab no reason other than thats just how things happened. Ive honestly never had a problem with fidelitys UIUX both the app and the website. iOS app has always been good. In my opinion, that shouldnt be the main reason to choose a broker. Obviously, if the appwebsite are shit then sure, dont go with that broker, but the main thing you should consider is which company is better for your money. Judging by your list, fidelity wins on that metric. Also, Ive had all good experiences with their customer service. My employer payed out our pensions last year and it was seamless to call fidelity to roll it over into an IRA.

Im happy with fidelity. I havent used Schwab, but have used a few others, and currently have a ibkr account. Ive been contemplating just sticking with fidelity exclusively. Between the app, trader pro, and their website, I feel like they have you covered with screnners and and all the chart indicators you really need. I havent noticed slippage yet when using limit orders, or anything like that. Doing anything over the phone seems easy and pleasant.

I agree with you about Schwabs app being glitchy. I have given up trying to do any trades on the app and only use it to do research. I only trade on PC because Schwabs app will just freeze up every time I try to do a trade on my phone. Also Schwab has locked people out of their accounts twice this year already which never happened to me before on any other brokerage. The only reason I am using Schwab is because I really liked TD Ameritrade and they were purchased by Schwab this year so I didnt really have a choice. I wanted to give them the benefit of the doubt and you can still use the ThinkorSwim platform with Schwab so that is something that I dont want to give up. I am crossing my fingers hoping they will get better because I would really rather avoid switching brokerages and having to learn a new skill set for trading. If I were to move I might choose Chase, but I have heard that Fidelity is also a good choice. Good luck with whatever you decide! Edit I wanted to add that another thing I do like about Schwab is that you can trade in afterhours premarket, set up as many automatic orders as you want with no fees for equity tradesnot options, and I can spend twice as much money as I actually have if I want to not sure if that is a good thing or not...lol.

I have accounts at both. I was switched to Schwab when they bought TD Ameritrade. After the switch, I was extremely disappointed with Schwab performance. Here are the things I did not like versus Fidelity 1 Fidelity auto sweeps my cash to a money market account paying 5. Schwab does not and pays a paltry 0.35 on this cash. 2 Fidelity pays out dividends to customers the same day companies pay out. Schwab holds this cash for an extra day and pays out a day later. 3 Schwabs site experienced 3 crashes at the open when I was looking to trade. Never had a problem with Fidelity in the 10 years I have had an account with them. 4 My account contacts at Fidelity are great and take care of things within days of requesting. My account rep at TD Ameritrade was awesome and moved over to Schwab. He is super frustrated by them due to their poor performance and inability to compete with other brokerage firms as they are not competitive. 5 Schwab only allows a single phone number for two factor authentication. Fidelity allows two phone numbers to be set up to access an account via two factor authentication. I want both my wife and myself to be able to access accounts in case something happens to the other spouse. I ended up moving a multimillion account from Schwab to Fidelity due to Schwabs poor performance. Fidelity paid me an incentive bonus of several thousand dollars to move the money to them. I am much happier.
Having both is the move, has been the move and will always be the move!
Schwab is known to crash during periods of high use since they took all of TD Ameritrade and brought everyone over. If it were easier? Id have left them.
The Schwab UI is ass. I was forced into this shit from TD and I hate it. Because of that I say fidelity. Anything is better what Schwab mobile app

replies.text: If youre talking about international shares, then quite a lot. For many high cost brokers SelfWealth, Stake, Pearler etc, youll often pay 0.51.0 each on the way in and out.

I think you mean IBKR? Interactive Brokers right? Depends on what you trade. If only domestic stocks, then near any will be fine. Just pick lowest or no fees. If you want international stocks, then Interactive Brokers is probably the only viable option. But IB has one glaring weakness, no treasury auction participation. I have no idea why they are behind on that feature. You can still buy treasuries on the open market but I prefer auctions. Easier to deal with.
Dont pick a broker that stops you from trading when trades go your way such as Robinhood.

I only have account with public company and an office near me if I need to walk in for business. A lot of easier to have them call internally resolve issues. Public company does not play games with irregularities.

Personally I use IKBR, Ive had an excellent experience with their customer service and I like their interface, plus I sometimes move from country to country and theyre wellequipped to deal with that. Their position in the market was also a big factor, if youre going to park tens or hundreds of thousands with somebody you want to be as sure as you can be they wont go bellyup.

The larger the brokerage, the more options you have for investing... more access to various funds , more ability to trade during extended hours , the more margin you can borrow , faster transfer times for moving money around , longer to pay off margin calls

You want a broker with nolow fees for the things you want to trade, one that ideally has a good and friendly user interface software, and one that is responsive when trying to contact them for anything good customer service. So in this respect, yes it matters.
Some brokers dont allow you to trade OTC stocks or after hours. Depends what you plan to trade.

IF you are listening to what they say....it might mean a lot. if you ignore their recommendations, and use your own knowledge to decide, and only use them as one source of potential investing data, that is smartest.

It used to matter a lot more in the past, when they all had more fees and different services. Robinhood unironically helped the industry by making a bunch of brokerages more friendly to customers with no trading fees.

For investing, Fidelity is my choice for multiple reasons such as ease of SPAXX cash management and their customer service. However, their installable trading platform is dogshit, so Im forced to use their web ui Trading Dashboard for anything to do with options. Tastytrade has the best installable platform for a small account with a focus on options in my opinion.

You have to know what matters to you. The most important thing for me is Interest rate. I sit on 30 cash so thats very important to me. Doesnt matter to me but order execution and minimum slippage is important for day traders. I hear Robin Hood and etrade is the worst for that. Not as important to me but maybe for you is fees and commissions for things like options if thats something you will get into later. Each broker will also have different margin requirements which also dont matter to me but can sabotage other traders
Im thinking of picking up Webull. Really like their charts and stuff. Avoid RobbinTheHood.

Or any other big brokers during the GME pump back then? Such bullshit every time RH comes up. In fact, the big brokers had problems lately during the big dip a few weeks ago. I couldnt log in and buy, while RH was just fine. Missed out on so much because of that. It just shows that most brokers would not handle the volume of users when a big event occurs.

Do you actually know what happened or are you being a sheep and just regurgitating what other people are saying? If you are referencing the GME saga explain to me how Robinhood was responsible for halting trade of GME across multiple brokers? You cant because it was apex clearing firm that was responsible for the halts. Maybe actually do some research next time before regurgitating crap?
Thats cause Robinhood doesnt have the liquidity to cover black swan events ... they will always protect themselves from extreme volatility
this!!!!!! they do that when tryna sell an option

I say to every single new investors and they are like why? Because of the gamestore? Thats a memestock so its fine. Ok? Does it matter what stock it is? Pretty scummy business model for a broker preventing one side of a trade to manipulate the price.
I know they run a lot of promos, have you considered waiting to get a better one? Im currently in the same boat

You probably have to update your KYC forms. They denied me for freaking NVDU which is just NVDA 2X leveraged etf. But I have a vanguard joint account with my wife so since she checked no experience with options and leveraged stuff they wont let me. Oh well.
If you look into the issue youll realize its not just robinhood but whoever uses apex clearing got affected
Fidelity couldnt even handle yesterdays situation with SMCI for 5 minutes between 920925.

Thats exactly why they IPOd they have plenty of liquidity now. All brokers are required to protect themselves and their customers during black swan events, its not a Robinhood decision, its legal requirement. The exchanges themselves kick in with circuit breakers, the stupid thing is most people think even those are Robinhood stopping trading when its a market level restriction. In fact, RH users are usually so uneducated that the company puts way more information in the banners about whats happening in the backend so that their users stop having conspiracy theories

They didnt need to provide liquidity themselves. They couldve easily just raised the price displayed on their platform to incentivise holders of GameStop to sell to the people who wanted to buy. No reason to deactivate the buy button.

Do you even know what youre talking about? Price manipulation is illegal for brokers to do. You have FINRA regulations that youre always trying your best to provide the best price to your customers. Also brokers are required by the DTCC to have enough liquidity to meet ratio requirements.

Well, if there were shares available on the exchanges at the price, they could just route the order to the exchange. But supposedly there were no shares for sale on the exchange which is why they had to freeze buying, but if that was the case, they couldve just raised the price and done OTC trades.

replies.text: rretirement is supportive and informative.

Isnt Edward Jones a financial advisor firm? Isnt she paying them already? If they are fiduciaries lordy, I hope so for those rates then you already have someone you can talk to about this. Also, I understand the desire to minimize taxes, but remember that someone is going to pay taxes on that money in CB at some point. If you move it to a Roth, then its already taxed and she or her heirs can pull it taxfree. AND its not subject to RMDs. It might be reasonable to just do a Roth conversion for the CB money or several over a couple years depending on where she is in the tax and IRMAA brackets. Max out the tax bracket shes in and you can probably convert in a couple years without triggering unnecessary taxes or and IRMAA cliff. Lastly, you posted this in a couple places .. .might as well hit rretirement as well. That seems like your target audience.
Corebridge sells annuities. It is not the same as a brokerage account and probably has featuresbenefits that youre not familiar with.

She has to take out a few thousand every year bc shes over a certain age. Youre describing RMD required minimum distribution, from a retirement account? Yes, the government requires this and provides the table for how much to take, based on the FMV of the accounts at prior year end and the persons age, which I dont see where you told us this important piece of information. but I also dont want her to have to pay 20 tax on the money right away. Anything that is removed from a taxable retirement account, such as Trad IRA or 401k, is taxable as ordinary income. It may or may not be 20. There is withholding, which is deducted at the time of the distribution, for retirement accounts. Thats likely the 20 you mention, which is not Taxes. Its a prepayment against her 1040. a big chunk in a vanguard 20 and then I invested the other 19. Vanguard is a brokerage. Which funds? Invested the other 19 in what? A perspective of the mix helps. Shes a single, widow, head of household thats old enough to hit any qualifier for tax stuff. Shes retired. The 5y rule wouldnt apply to her, I know that. Yes, there are a number of 5year rules for Roth. Yes, the accountbased Roth IRA fiveyear rule says you cannot withdraw earnings taxfree until its been at least five years since you first contributed to a Roth IRA account. This fiveyear rule applies to everyone who contributes to a Roth IRA, whether theyre 59 12 or 105 years old. It will depend, then, and when she takes funds and how much as compared to her basis. From Yes, another Roth 5year rule is for conversions. Each carries its own 5year clock. She wont be subject to this rule. ideally some kind of welcome bonus even if its 150200 bucks You dont need a Bonus for retirement investing. You dont need to work on incentives. You just need to work on being helpful and getting her some lower risk with better performance. It isnt clear if CB is holding annuities for this person. That one of the investment types, and not an account, and thats why it matters to note the holdings. Yes, you would talk to the ED Jones person, but they are paid advisor group. You also can Rollover a Trad IRA to a Vanguard IRA this means Account and then investreinvest the holdings. You can do a direct trusteetotrustee transfer for the holdings, often in kind from a Trad IRA to a Roth IRA, but that is a taxable conversion. I do not recommend conversions unless the person is under 70 or really wont touch this money for 1015 years. Thats because they are already taking RMDs and paying taxes, so moving it and paying taxes, then needing to take some as distributions anyway, just churned their account a bit. And as pointed out, watch her income tax bracket, for triggering IRMAA. Thats an expensive lesson.

I just reread this section I could hopefully put 8500 in a Roth in 24, then put whatever the max is in 25 which I assume will be at least 9500. Those limits relate to posttax retirement contributions, not conversions. Contributions are new money socked away. Youre eligible because you have earned income, such as wages or other work compensation. None of this idea relates to your retiree.

I am well aware Im clueless when it comes to this. I was really just looking for resources. I appreciate all of the advice Ive gotten from the few subs Ive posted this in, really been a big help. Ive objectively been a positive benefit on her finances and not getting scammed, I was literally at her house when she was about to get scammed for who knows how much...her friend got taken for her savings which is awful. She was mid download of a remote control phone app, no joke. But I know what I know, and I know what Im absolutely fucking clueless about. At least thats what my therapist says, just in a much softer tone. It was one thing to get from some savings account paying her 0.05 APY that she NEVER touched in to a HYSA. That was even pulling teeth tbh, took months before she agreed, but shes been super open with me and now thinks I know way more than I do lol. Shes also getting more forgetful which is rough to see, and her sons arent around as much as they should be. Shes basically been my mother, I lost mine at 13, dad not long after and she was always there. So I want to be there for her. Ive already talked to a couple places for free and gotten some solid info. Still in very early stages of this, I want to have her sit down with a financial advisor at least once with regards to this account. She seems open to it, she wants me there which is fine. I want to make sure I find the right one, and shes the busiest person her age Ive ever seen lol. Im in no rush though, I want to make that very clear. Shes in the middle of switching CPAs as well, the one she had for 25y retired and she simply just kept going to whoever took over the place. Since then, shes had to pay late fees to the IRS 23 years... albeit very minor, like low 3 figures minor, but still which is ridiculous. No issues like that for 25y, then in the 3y shes been with this new guy there was a mess up like that twice? She said she basically never sees the guy either, has spent maybe a total of 10 minutes in his office in 3 years. Luckily her son has had one for a long time, and its closer than hers was. So thatll be good. Anyway thanks again guys. Best wishes.
Thx

Shes earning like 2 APY on the vast majority of the money. Its a retirement account, some of it is invested in to a vanguard ETF or whatever. She gets 10 every year via RMD, so shes gonna pay those taxes regardless. She also doesnt like having the in the account, shes never heard of CB, and shes never met the person in charge of her account. The only benefit I can see is she doesnt have to pay taxes on it right now, but like I said 10 comes out every year which she has to pay taxes on.
Edward Jones is expensive. Consider shopping around for another custodian.

Someone told me Fidelity would give me basic advice free. That on top of a free consultation from a financial advisor, those the two things on my to do list for sure. I dont particularly trust EJ, theyd probably just tell her to do whatever they could to max profits and get that in their hands. First question you need to ask any of them is, are you a fiduciary, bound to give advice that benefits XXXX? They have a legal obligation to act in the best interest of you or in this case your relative instead of the company they work for. Someone asked me why I want her to make on her , which I thought was a wild question. Isnt that the point? Just bc she can pay her expenses means she shouldnt make more money? Yeah, this is just weird. As if she wouldnt want to leave a legacy i.e., money to her heirs, charity, etc. I mean making sure shes taken care of is paramount, but if she had the ability to do more I would think she would want to.

What I found so crazy about all of that was just the lack of understanding of how expensive it is to produce an entirely new vehicle. The major auto makers would often collaborate or at a minimum share parts between platforms to reduce the cost. The first Tesla wasnt even really bespoke, it was a modified Lotus with bespoke body panels. Tesla was unprofitable for a long time, and also only got over their initial first delivery hump because of a DOE grant that was part of an Obama administration sustainable energy program. And they still didnt turn a profit for years. It takes a long time to get a reactor built. New designs take a long time to be reviewed and approved, and for good reason. If something goes sideways it can have catastrophic impacts to health and safety. It takes years to get a plant built as it goes through the community planning process. And in all that time that it takes to get it up and running there is a lot of room for people to be taken by the next great thing. True advances in any technology are great, and a lot of people recognize the issue of climate change and how power hungry data centers are. But advances in technology also mean more efficient use of power and materials to do the same thing. For me that is how companies really separate themselves from the pack, if theyre coming up with a more efficient product, running their operations more efficiently, truly innovating and rapidly meeting a need. I dont see nuclear doing that soon.

Hi, I think that an important distinction has to be done between nuclear and uranium Nuclear stocks are companies that build reactors. Uranium stocks are companies actif in the fuel of reactors I think indeed that investing in nuclear stocks is much more risky than investing in uranium producers. Nuclear stocks in the West have a lot to study, to reinvent. In China, India, Russia reactors are build on time and close to budget. And they finish a lot of new reactors each year! In the West we had that in the 80ties and 90ties. But now the West lost that, and has to reinvent that level of nuclear reactor construction. Uranium producers or near term producers well advanced developers on the other hand have a very bright future The uranium sector is in a structural growing supply deficit that cant be solved in a couple years time The near term producers, like Peninsula Energy, Lotus Resources, Global Atomic, and smaller uranium producers steadily increasing production, like EnCore Energy, Uranium Energy Corp, Denison Mines, will greatly benefit from this structural shortage, but they are too small to solve that global uranium supply shortage. Kazatomprom, Cameco, Orano, CGN, ..., and a couple smaller uranium producers are all selling more uranium to clients than they produce Because they are forced to by their clients through existing LT contracts with an option to flex up uranium demand from clients. Meaning that they will all together try to buy uranium through the iliquide uranium spotmarket, while the biggest uranium supplier of the spotmarket has less uranium to sell. And the less they deliver to clients utilities, the more clients will have to find uranium in the spotmarket directly. There is no way around this. Producers andor clients, someone is going to buy more uranium in the spotmarket. And that while uranium demand is price INelastic! And before that announcement in August 2024 of Kazakhstan that they will produce 17 less in 2025 than previously promised, the global uranium supply problem looked like this Source Cameco using data from UxC, 1 of 2 global sector consultants for all uranium producers and uranium consumers in world Kazakhstan represents 45 of world uranium production. This isnt financial advice. Please do your own due diligence before investing Cheers

Working in the nuclear sector I think people underestimate the cost aspect and the time the design process takes. From my time working at CPNPP, the plant first ran in the 90s, the majority of equipment approved for the build was built in the 70s. When I was there in 2016 time frame we had a DOS based plc hooked to fax machine that printed out every line of code in the plant line by line just like in the Simpsons an it was so outdated we had to 3D print our parts to rebuild the fax machine. lol The maintenance teams are great at making old shit work. In the 70s it took them 16 years to build and 11 billion roughly spent. In 2016 the two reactors produced roughly 3 million in profit a day 1.5m per reactor no telling what that is now or what that was 20 years ago. CPNPP averaged roughly 6 of Texas produced energy with its two reactors. Nuclear Power has a bell curve to be profitable and provide clean energy for decades. UAEs 4 reactor Barakah plant is a great representation of this however, the US private sector relies heavily on the government whom is currently afraid to take a risk on nuclear and they have been steadily declining to do so for years. Due to this lack of investing and advancement well continue to hinder ourselves by not taking those necessary risks to drive efficiency in Nuclear power.

During the day orders are placed with market or limit orders. A market order will go through regardless of price at the lowest available price. When hedgefunds or institutions place buysell orders a lot of the time they will just do it to buysell x amt of shares and not based on the price well maybe with a limit of like x of the current price. So pretty much a buy order from multiple source at or above 140 woulda had to go through to break that sell wall. It was unlikely, but the stock was breaking out hard.

Car makers currently struggle with many things. While the conservative sales are mostly attributed to buyers being under financial pressure, personally I believe, a far more relevant reason is, that car buyers make competent decisions. Those, who are hell bent on fossile fuel cars will delay their next car buy as much as possible. Why? Because they know, those cars will disappear and they intend to drive their last one as long as possible. EV buyers on the other hand wait out their buy, because the technology is making massive strives and buying two years from now means, you will get a much more sophisticated product at a time, when significantly better infrastructure has been built. Overall this will blunt the market for cars in the west for the next 5 years Assuming, there will be no possible measures by goverments to greatly incentivise buying EVs now. That would change things. There should be a massive run however at the end of that phase. Tesla adds a whole new problem to that general issue of car builders though. Elon Musk is massively and publicly and aggressively at odds with the views of his most important customer base. There may only be one company that has publicly declared to buy no more Tesla, but others will silently decide that turning up with Teslas at their customers will send the wrong signal. This means, buyers for car fleets which bought Tesla to project a liberal, open, visionary mindset will stop buying. And these people are a pretty big market. And its a market, that will not wait out the next halfdecade. As for the other things Yes, Tesla is doing a lot of stuff. And some of that stuff basically finances the Elondepression in car sales. But there is a problem. And its Elon. Because a lot of his projects look like a deeply homonal teenager with no impulse control is just trying to fulfill all of his dreams. And thats fine for a billionaire to do. Some of what he does will massively improve the future and you need to be a little crazy to do that. But if you run those dreams as a business, its a red flag. And a CEO, who increasingly seems to regress into a teenagers level of self control is a massive liability.

This is another example of UIS analysis that downplays GAAP accounting and looks at the company's incessant pension outlays, etc., as a smokescreen for an outfit that continues to operate despite horrible reported losses.

James:  Read the quarterly and annual reports.  On a GAAP basis, UIS bleeds, largely as a result of defined benefit pension liabilities and contributions or offloading of same.  These balance sheet transactions effectively shelter UIS's operations, which are cash flow positive.  This distinction is noted in the annual reports, which state clearly that the loss carryforwards will shelter UIS against taxes for years to come.  As @thechannelman has noted, the stock price has significant gyrations that don't reflect fundamentals.  Take a gander at what Joseph Vafi of Cannacord Genuity says about the company. He lowered his rating from a buy to a hold a few years back.  But he sees better things coming in 2025.  FYI, I've written covered calls against this at 7 bucks and made this a dividend stock.  Nuts, but there are times that may be appropriate.   I suspect interest rate cuts will help share price.  They are facing significant debt payments in coming years; lower interest might help with refinancing.
